Award.AwardTitle: A New Avenue to Promote Lanthanide Ion Emission
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project, funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms B Program of the Chemistry Division of the National Science Foundation, Professor Ana de Bettencourt-Dias and her research group at the University of Nevada, Reno, decorate the surfaces of diverse nanoparticles with lanthanide ions and assess the ability of these nanoparticles to sensitize lanthanide luminescence. The materials developed have potential application as bioimaging agents. The project involves training of undergraduate and graduate students, as well as postdoctoral researchers, in the synthesis of nanoparticles, organic molecules and lanthanide ion complexes, as well as modern emission and absorption spectroscopic techniques. Student researchers gain experience in writing manuscripts describing their research for publication. To further improve the students' ability to write scientific manuscripts, Prof. de Bettencourt-Dias has developed and will continue improving a course on scientific writing. Topics such as strategies to increase writing productivity, outlining of research manuscripts and graduate theses, the ethics of using published sources and resume writing for job searching in industry are included.

Lanthanide ions are light emitters due to transitions within the 4f orbitals. These transitions and the light emission are most easily promoted through coordinated chromophores. As part of this project, the nanoparticle surfaces are functionalized with existing and with new ligands that serve to increase their aqueous solubility and biocompatibility; the ligands also coordinate the lanthanide ions and serve as mediators for the energy transfer. With the help of spectroscopic techniques such as fluorescence, the efficiency of the energy transfer will be assessed and parameters will be developed for improvement of the luminescence properties and for the future use of these decorated nanoparticles in bioimaging applications.

Institution.Name: Board of Regents, NSHE, obo University of Nevada, Reno

Performance_Institution.Name: Board of Regents, NSHE, obo University of Nevada, Reno

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The group of Prof. de Bettencourt-Dias explores the promotion of luminescence in lanthanide ions, which are located in the f block of the periodic table. The sensitization of luminescence is done most efficiently through indirect excitation, through either coordinated organic ligands or through nanoparticles. The latter mode of sensitization was the main avenue explored in this proposal. With the help of undergraduate and graduate students, the research group was able to demonstrate the isolation of nanoparticles functionalized with ligands capable of binding to lanthanide ions. These systems displayed the expected metal-centered emission.

More specifically, we decorated the surface of zinc sulfide and cadmium sulfide nanoparticles, with mercaptopropionato and found that the metal ion-centered emission is observed upon excitation through the nanoparticle. A similar result was obtained when metal-containing nanoparticles were substituted for carbon dots that have carbonyl and carboxylato surface groups capable of binding the lanthanide ions and are able to efficiently transfer energy and effect metal-centered emission. These were among the first examples of visible lanthanide ion emission sensitized directly through appended nanoparticles; usually isolating ligands with tailored energy levels can lead to complicated syntheses. In nanoparticles, the size of the bandgap and thus position of the energy levels are dictated by their size, which can be controlled by growth time.

We also showed that we can incorporate lanthanide ions into polycarbonate-based polymers to isolate soluble polymeric systems with high emission efficiency for red europium, green terbium and blue thulium emission. Appropriate choice of ratios of europium and terbium polymers resulted in systems with nearly perfect white light, as shown by the CIE chromaticity diagram. These polycarbonato-based materials dissolved in a variety of solvents, which facilitated their characterization, as well as the formation of the materials with the white light emission.

The graduate and undergraduate students involved in the project learned the basics of synthesis, including advanced inert gas synthetic techniques, and advanced spectroscopic techniques. They helped draft manuscripts for publication, and presented their work during research group meetings and at national meetings of the American Chemical Society and an international f element conference, the Rare Earth Research Conference. They also were involved in a collaboration with a research group that provided their expertise and training in polymer characterization techniques.

 


Last Modified: 05/17/2019
Modified by: Ana De Bettencourt-Dias

Image
  • CIE chromaticity diagram and inset with photo of luminescent polymer solutions. The diagram shows that judicious embedding of appropriate ratios of the red and green emitting lanthanide ions leads to nearly perfect white light.
    Rodney Tigaa, Ana de Bettencourt-Dias
    Ana De Bettencourt-Dias
    CIE chromaticity diagram
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The group of Prof. de Bettencourt-Dias explores the promotion of luminescence in lanthanide ions, which are located in the f block of the periodic table. The sensitization of luminescence is done most efficiently through indirect excitation, through either coordinated organic ligands or through nanoparticles. The latter mode of sensitization was the main avenue explored in this proposal. With the help of undergraduate and graduate students, the research group was able to demonstrate the isolation of nanoparticles functionalized with ligands capable of binding to lanthanide ions. These systems displayed the expected metal-centered emission. More specifically, we decorated the surface of zinc sulfide and cadmium sulfide nanoparticles, with mercaptopropionato and found that the metal ion-centered emission is observed upon excitation through the nanoparticle. A similar result was obtained when metal-containing nanoparticles were substituted for carbon dots that have carbonyl and carboxylato surface groups capable of binding the lanthanide ions and are able to efficiently transfer energy and effect metal-centered emission. These were among the first examples of visible lanthanide ion emission sensitized directly through appended nanoparticles; usually isolating ligands with tailored energy levels can lead to complicated syntheses. In nanoparticles, the size of the bandgap and thus position of the energy levels are dictated by their size, which can be controlled by growth time. We also showed that we can incorporate lanthanide ions into polycarbonate-based polymers to isolate soluble polymeric systems with high emission efficiency for red europium, green terbium and blue thulium emission. Appropriate choice of ratios of europium and terbium polymers resulted in systems with nearly perfect white light, as shown by the CIE chromaticity diagram. These polycarbonato-based materials dissolved in a variety of solvents, which facilitated their characterization, as well as the formation of the materials with the white light emission. The graduate and undergraduate students involved in the project learned the basics of synthesis, including advanced inert gas synthetic techniques, and advanced spectroscopic techniques. They helped draft manuscripts for publication, and presented their work during research group meetings and at national meetings of the American Chemical Society and an international f element conference, the Rare Earth Research Conference. They also were involved in a collaboration with a research group that provided their expertise and training in polymer characterization techniques.
